text: Bless the LORD, ye his angels, that excel in strength, that do his commandments, hearkening unto the voice of his word.
text_kjv: Bless the LORD, ye his angels, that excel in strength, that do his commandments, hearkening unto the voice of his word.
text_niv: Praise the Lord, you his angels,you mighty ones who do his bidding,who obey his word.
text_esv: Bless the LORD, O you his angels, you mighty ones who do his word, obeying the voice of his word!
text_nlt: Praise the LORD, you angels,you mighty ones who carry out his plans,listening for each of his commands.
text_msg: So bless God, you angels,ready and able to fly at his bidding,quick to hear and do what he says.
text_nasb: Bless the LORD, you His angels, Mighty in strength, who perform His word, Obeying the voice of His word!
context: Psalm 103 is a hymn of praise attributed to David, overflowing with gratitude for God's boundless grace, mercy, and loving-kindness. To fully grasp verse 20, it's crucial to understand the ancient Israelite worldview concerning angels. In the Old Testament, angels were primarily understood as messengers and agents of God's will, forming part of the divine court. They were not viewed as independent entities but extensions of God's power and authority. The concept of angels existing in a hierarchy, with some excelling in strength, was prevalent. This imagery resonates with the political structures of ancient Near Eastern kingdoms, where a king's power was manifested through his loyal and powerful officials. The term 'angels' (Hebrew: *mal'akim*) simply means 'messengers,' highlighting their function of carrying out God's commands. The psalm reflects a cosmic praise – not just from humans but also from the heavenly host. David’s likely familiarity with temple worship, involving choirs and instruments, might have influenced his envisioning of angels collectively praising God. David's own life, marked by divine deliverance from numerous threats, probably shaped his acute awareness of God's protective presence mediated, in his understanding, by angels. Royal psalms often invoked divine assistance against enemies, and the inclusion of angels in this call to praise suggests a comprehensive mobilization of all creation to acknowledge God's sovereignty and goodness. The mention of 'hearkening unto the voice of his word' indicates an obedience rooted in intimate understanding and submission to God's revealed will.
meaning: Theologically, Psalm 103:20 reinforces the idea of God's absolute sovereignty and control over all creation, both seen and unseen. The angels, described as 'excelling in strength,' represent the immense power at God's disposal. Their obedience to God's commandments is not merely compliance but an active 'hearkening' – a deep attentiveness and responsiveness to His voice. This implies a relationship of intimate communication and unwavering loyalty. The verse underscores the idea that even the most powerful beings in the cosmos are subject to God's authority. Their purpose is to carry out His will, illustrating the divine order and harmony of creation. The Hebrew word for 'commandments' (*dabar*) also carries the weight of 'word' or 'decree,' connecting the actions of the angels directly to God's spoken will. This highlights the power and efficacy of God's word itself. By commanding the angels to bless the Lord, David isn't instructing them in something they don't already do, but rather acknowledging and celebrating their perpetual worship. The verse serves as a call to all creation to join in the praise of God, emphasizing the universality of His dominion and the all-encompassing nature of His glory. It implicitly contrasts with human disobedience, highlighting the angels' unwavering fidelity as a model for human conduct. It also hints at a divinely ordained hierarchy, reflecting the complex and ordered structure of the cosmos as understood in ancient Israel.
application: Psalm 103:20 offers several practical applications for modern believers. Firstly, it encourages us to cultivate a deeper awareness of the unseen realm and the spiritual forces at work around us. While we may not directly interact with angels in the same way as figures in the Old Testament, recognizing their role as agents of God's will can inspire a greater sense of God's active presence in our lives. Secondly, the verse challenges us to emulate the angels' obedience to God's commands. This involves actively seeking to understand God's will through Scripture, prayer, and discernment, and then diligently striving to live in accordance with His principles. 'Hearkening unto the voice of his word' implies a willingness to listen attentively to God's guidance and to respond promptly and faithfully. This requires a disciplined approach to spiritual growth, prioritizing time for reflection and meditation on God's word. Thirdly, the verse calls us to participate in the cosmic chorus of praise. We are invited to join the angels in blessing the Lord, acknowledging His sovereignty and expressing gratitude for His countless blessings. This can manifest in various forms of worship, including prayer, singing, acts of service, and sharing our faith with others. Fourthly, recognizing the angels' strength and obedience can be a source of encouragement in times of difficulty. Knowing that God has powerful and loyal agents working on His behalf can strengthen our faith and give us hope in the face of adversity. Finally, the verse can serve as a reminder of our responsibility to steward God's creation faithfully. Just as the angels fulfill their divine purpose, we are called to use our gifts and talents to serve God and to care for the world around us. By aligning our lives with God's will, we become instruments of His grace and contribute to the ongoing manifestation of His kingdom on earth.
prayer: Heavenly Father, I am humbled by the thought of your angels, those mighty beings who excel in strength and obey your every command. I thank you for their unwavering devotion and their role in carrying out your divine purposes. Forgive me for the times I have been slow to listen to your voice or reluctant to follow your guidance. Grant me a heart that is attentive to your word and a spirit that is willing to obey your will. Help me to join the angels in blessing your name, expressing my gratitude for your boundless love and mercy. Strengthen my faith in times of difficulty, reminding me that you are sovereign and that your angels are always working on your behalf. May my life be a reflection of your grace and a testament to your glory. In Jesus' name, I pray. Amen.

faqs.answer: No, Psalm 103:20 is a call to bless the Lord, echoed by the angels. It describes the angels praising God, not an invitation for us to pray to them. We pray to God alone, through Jesus Christ, as our mediator. The angels' example inspires us to join in worship, but not to direct our prayers to them.
faqs.question: Q1: Does Psalm 103:20 mean we should pray to angels?

faqs.answer: The phrase highlights the angels' extraordinary power and ability to execute God's will effectively. Their strength is not independent but derived from God, reflecting His own boundless power. This strength is used to carry out His purposes, protect His people, and uphold His divine order.
faqs.question: Q2: What does it mean for angels to 'excel in strength'?

faqs.answer: We hearken to God's word through consistent Bible reading, prayerful meditation, and seeking the guidance of the Holy Spirit. It involves not just hearing the words but actively applying them to our lives, allowing them to shape our thoughts, actions, and attitudes, and obeying his commands.
faqs.question: Q3: How can we 'hearken' to the voice of God's word today?

faqs.answer: Yes, the phrase 'excel in strength' suggests a hierarchy among angels, with varying degrees of authority and responsibility. While the Bible doesn't provide a comprehensive angelology, it does indicate different ranks and roles within the angelic host, all ultimately under God's command.
faqs.question: Q4: Does this verse imply a hierarchy among angels?

faqs.answer: Psalm 103 is about praising God for his mercy and benefits. Verse 20 extends the call to praise to the angels, highlighting the universal nature of God's dominion and the unified chorus of worship from both the earthly and heavenly realms. It reinforces God's sovereignty.
